newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ First, Labour start coalition talks.
newsitem.headline: NZ First, Labour start coalition talks.

text.p: The main opposition Labour Party and nationalist New Zealand First on Wednesday met for their first round of negotiations aimed at forming a new government.
Labour leader Helen Clark, who arrived 10 minutes early for the scheduled 10 a.m. start, said she expected the meeting to set procedures for the negotiations.
Asked her preferred timetable for the talks, Clark said: "Sooner rather than later".

Her negotiating team comprised finance spokesman Michael Cullen, party president Michael Hirschfeld, chief whip Jonathan Hunt, Maori list MP Dover Samuels, third ranked MP Steve Maharey and Clark's policy advisor Heather Simpson.
The New Zealand First team arrived a few minutes late, with leader Winston Peters declining comment to the waiting media.

His team was the same that opened talks with the caretaker National Party government on Monday -- deputy leader Tau Henare, president and list MP Doug Woolerton, MP Peter McCardle and Peters' brother, lawyer Wayne Peters.

The venue for the preliminary talks, which are expected to focus on procedure for substantive negotiations and the confidentiality agreement that Peters is seeking, was made known in advance. That was in contrast to the secrecy surrounding New Zealand First's meeting with National on Monday.
National and NZ First are due to hold their second session on Wednesday afternoon.

After the October 12 election New Zealand First holds the balance of power between the conservative National government and its supporters on the right, and Labour and the Alliance on the left. It plans to negotiate simultaneously with both
National and Labour in a process which is expected to take some weeks. -- Wellington Newsroom (64 4) 4734746
